name: Appendix
description: The vermiform appendix is a blind-ended tube with a narrow irregular lumen. Its most characteristic feature is the presence of abundant lymphoid follicles in the submucosa and lamina propria.

features: Small, irregular lumen filled with debris
Abundant lymphoid follicles in submucosa (ring of lymphatic tissue)
Crypts of Lieberkühn present but irregular
Muscularis externa: continuous longitudinal layer (no taeniae coli)
Mesoappendix attached to serosa
theory.examTips: Identify by: 'Colon-like' features (crypts) + 'Tonsil-like' features (lymphoid follicles) + small diameter. Unlike colon, it has a continuous longitudinal muscle coat. Inflammation = Appendicitis (neutrophils in muscularis propria).

name: Colon
description: The colon (large intestine) functions in water absorption and mucous secretion. Its mucosa is smooth (no villi/plicae) and contains straight tubular glands (Crypts of Lieberkühn).

features: Mucosa: simple columnar epithelium with MANY goblet cells
Absence of villi and plicae circulares
Straight tubular, test-tube shaped Crypts of Lieberkühn
Taeniae coli: 3 distinct bands of outer longitudinal muscle
Pericryptal fibroblast sheath
function: Vitamin K synthesis by gut bacteria
theory.examTips: Distinguish from small intestine by ABSENCE of villi. Distinguish from appendix by arrangement of longitudinal muscle (taeniae coli present in colon, continuous in appendix). 'Test-tube' crypts + abundant goblet cells = Colon.

name: Myenteric Plexus
description: The myenteric plexus (Auerbach's plexus) is a network of autonomic ganglia and nerve fibers located between the inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layers of the muscularis externa.

features: Clusters of large neuronal cell bodies (ganglion cells)
Located BETWEEN inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layers
Surrounded by satellite cells (glial cells)
Unmyelinated nerve fiber bundles
Pale-staining nuclei with prominent nucleoli
location: Throughout GIT from esophagus to rectum
theory.examTips: Look for a pale-staining cluster of cells sandwiched between the two thick eosinophilic muscle layers. Hirschsprung disease = congenital absence (aganglionosis) of these plexuses in distal colon. Compare with Meissner's plexus (in submucosa).

name: Oesophageal Mucosa
description: The oesophageal mucosa is protective, lined by thick non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. It endures abrasion from swallowed food boluses.

features: Epithelium: Non-keratinized stratified squamous (thick)
Lamina propria: Loose connective tissue, cardiac glands (near stomach)
Muscularis mucosae: Single longitudinal layer (unusually thick)
Papillae of connective tissue indent epithelium
Basal cells: Regenerative layer
theory.examTips: Key ID: Thick stratified squamous epithelium WITHOUT keratin. Muscularis mucosae is longitudinally oriented and thick. Barrett's Esophagus: Metaplasia to columnar epithelium due to chronic reflux (risk of adenocarcinoma).

name: Oesophagus
description: The oesophagus is a muscular tube transporting food to the stomach. Key features include non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and a muscularis externa that transitions from skeletal to smooth muscle.

features: Mucosa: Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Submucosa: Esophageal glands proper (mucous)
Muscularis Externa: Upper 1/3 skeletal, Middle 1/3 mixed, Lower 1/3 smooth
Adventitia (mostly) or Serosa (short abdominal part)
Folded mucosa (star-shaped lumen)
function: Upper Esophageal Sphincter: Prevents air entry
Lower Esophageal Sphincter: Prevents acid reflux
theory.examTips: Esophagus is the ONLY part of GIT with squamous epithelium (except anal canal). Muscularis externa transition is classic: Striated (voluntary swallowing) -> Smooth (involuntary peristalsis). Lack of serosa facilitates spread of esophageal cancer.

name: Salivary gland
description: Salivary glands are exocrine glands with acini (secretory units) and a duct system. The major glands (parotid, submandibular, sublingual) vary in preventing acinar type (serous vs. mucous).

features: Secretory Acini: Serous (dark, enzymes), Mucous (pale, mucin), or Mixed (serous demilunes)
Ducts: Intercalated (cuboidal), Striated (columnar, basal striations), Excretory
Myoepithelial cells contractile cells around acini
Septa dividing gland into lobules
Parotid = Pure Serous; Submandibular = Mixed (Mostly Serous); Sublingual = Mixed (Mostly Mucous)
theory.examTips: Identify gland type by acini: Parotid is dark/basophilic (all serous). Sublingual is pale (mostly mucous). Submandibular is mixed. Serous demilunes (crescents) are artifacts of fixation found in mixed glands. Striated ducts resorb Na+.

name: Small bowel
description: The small intestine is the primary site of absorption, characterized by surface area increasing structures: Plicae circulares, Villi, and Microvilli.

features: Villi: Finger-like mucosal projections (Core of lamina propria + lacteal)
Crypts of Lieberkühn: Intestinal glands at base of villi
Enterocytes: Simple columnar with microvilli (brush border)
Goblet cells (increase distally)
Paneth cells (anti-bacterial) at crypt bases
theory.examTips: Duodenum: Brunner's glands in SUBMUCOSA (alkaline secretion). Jejunum: Tallest villi, no glands in submucosa. Ileum: Peyer's patches (lymphoid aggregations) in submucosa. 'Leaves on a tree' appearance of villi.

name: Gastric Antrum
description: The gastric antrum is the distal stomach containing deep gastric pits and mucous-secreting glands. It is responsible for gastrin secretion.

features: Pits > Glands (Pits occupy ~50% of mucosal thickness)
Glands are branched, coiled, tubuloalveolar
Cells: Mostly mucus-secreting cells
G cells (Gastrin) present
Few/No parietal or chief cells compared to body
theory.examTips: Antrum vs Body: Antrum has DEEP pits and coiled mucous glands. Body has shallow pits and straight glands rich in Parietal (acid) and Chief (pepsin) cells. H. pylori preferentially colonizes the antrum.

name: Gastric Foveolae
description: Gastric foveolae (pits) are invaginations of the surface epithelium into the lamina propria. They are lined by surface mucous cells that secrete a protective bicarbonate-rich mucus.

features: Lined by tall simple columnar surface mucous cells
Apical mucin cap (insoluble mucus)
Continuous with gastric glands at the isthmus
Depth varies by region (Shallow in body, Deep in antrum)
Protect against autodigestion
location: Luminal surface of entire stomach mucosa
function: Secretion of visible, viscous, alkaline mucus
theory.examTips: Don't confuse pits with villi. Villi project OUT, Pits go IN. In histological section, pits look like channels opening to the surface. Surface mucous cells (pits) differ from Mucous neck cells (gland neck) which secrete soluble mucus.

name: Normal Stomach
description: The stomach body/fundus contains simple branched tubular glands producing acid and enzymes. Key cell types include Parietal cells (acid) and Chief cells (pepsinogen).

features: Pits < Glands (Pits occupy ~25% of thickness)
Straight vertical tubular glands
Parietal cells: Eosinophilic, fried-egg appearance (upper gland)
Chief cells: Basophilic, granular (lower gland)
Three muscle layers: Oblique, Circular, Longitudinal
function: Production of Intrinsic Factor (absorption of Vit B12)
theory.examTips: Parietal = Pink (Acidophilic), Pumps Protons. Chief = Blue (Basophilic), Creates Proteins (enzymes). Autoimmune gastritis targets parietal cells -> Pernicious Anemia (B12 deficiency).

name: Pylorus
description: The pylorus connects the stomach to the duodenum. It is characterized by deep pits, mucus-secreting pyloric glands, and a thickened circular muscle layer forming the pyloric sphincter.

features: Similar to antrum: Deep pits, coiled mucous glands
Thickened middle circular muscle layer (Sphincter)
Lymphoid nodules often present
Enteroendocrine cells (G cells, D cells)
Absence of parietal/chief cells
theory.examTips: Hypertrophy of the circular muscle layer in infants = Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (projectile vomiting). Pylorus histology is 'Mucous + Muscle'. The sphincter is a true anatomical sphincter.

name: Tongue
description: The tongue is a muscular organ covered by stratified squamous epithelium with papillae on the dorsal surface. It contains interlacing bundles of skeletal muscle in three planes.

features: Interlacing skeletal muscle fibers (vertical, transverse, longitudinal)
Filiform papillae: numerous, conical, keratinized (no taste buds)
Fungiform papillae: mushroom-shaped, non-keratinized, taste buds on top
Circumvallate papillae: large, taste buds on sides, glands of von Ebner
Minor salivary glands embedded in muscle
theory.examTips: Muscle fibers running in ALL directions = Tongue. Filiform = Flame-shaped (friction, no taste). Fungiform = Mushroom (Taste). Circumvallate = Valleys (Taste + Washing by von Ebner glands). Posterior 1/3 has lingual tonsils.

name: Tonsil (Palatine Tonsil)
description: The palatine tonsils are lymphoid organs covered by stratified squamous epithelium that dips deeply to form tonsillar crypts. They lack afferent lymphatics.

features: Covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Deep tonsillar crypts (often contain debris)
Abundant lymphoid follicles with germinal centers
Partial connective tissue capsule (hemicapsule)
Mucous glands OUTSIDE the capsule
location: Between palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches (tonsillar fossa)
theory.examTips: Distinguish from lymph node: Tonsil has Epithelium (crypts) and NO subcapsular sinus. Palatine tonsil = Stratified Squamous. Pharyngeal tonsil (Adenoid) = Respiratory Epithelium. 'Crypt abscesses' = white spots in tonsillitis.
